docs.title: Infra Bootstrap
docs.text:
Welcome to Infra Bootstrap—your one-stop Bash framework for spinning up DevOps tools and Kubernetes labs in disposable environments. Modular scripts for fast, repeatable setups: From system checks to full clusters.

No bloat. No deps. Just curl | bash and run.

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Clone and bootstrap:

# Check system
curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/system-checks/preflight.sh | sudo bash

docs.title: Sections Overview
docs.text:
• System Checks: Validate your environment first.
  • Kubernetes: Self-managed clusters, CNI, addons.
  • Server Builds: Pre-configured labs like Jenkins, Jumpbox.
  • Components: Standalone binaries (Docker, Terraform, etc.).
  • Services: Containerized tools (SonarQube, Nexus etc. via Docker Compose).

Built for labs, not production. Harden as needed.

docs.title: Cli flags
docs.text:
Command Line Flags

Most infra-bootstrap installers support the following flags:

- `-q` → Quiet mode (suppresses interactive prompts)  
- `--no-update` → Skip package index refresh  
- `-h` / `--help` → Display help menu  

Flags allow installers to run in:
- CI pipelines  
- Automated provisioning workflows  
- Non-interactive sessions

docs.title: Common header
docs.text:
Lab Environment Only

This tool is intended for ephemeral, short-lived lab environments and is not hardened for production use.

docs.title: Error handling
docs.text:
Error Handling

All infra-bootstrap components use strict error handling:

- `set -e` ensures the script stops on any failure  
- `set -o pipefail` propagates failures inside pipelines  
- A `trap` handler prints the failing line number for debugging  

This prevents partial installations and ensures a **predictable, clean state** regardless of the failure point.

docs.title: Hostname config
docs.text:
Hostname Configuration

If quiet mode is disabled, the script will prompt for hostname modification.

Updating the hostname is useful when:
- Building multi-node Kubernetes clusters
- Creating named jump servers
- Assigning meaningful labels to lab environments

Hostname changes use `hostnamectl` and take effect immediately.

docs.title: Post installation
docs.text:
Post-Installation Verification

After installation completes, it is recommended to:

1. Validate the installed version  
2. Ensure the service is running (if applicable)  
3. Confirm CLI availability  
4. Run a basic operational command  

Tool-specific verification steps are provided in the sections below each installer.

docs.title: Preflight
docs.text:
Preflight Validation

Before any infra-bootstrap component begins installation, a full system preflight check is executed using preflight.sh.

The preflight check ensures:

- The script is executed with **root privileges**
- Required dependencies (`curl`, `bash`) are available
- The system has **working internet connectivity**
- The operating system is officially supported (Ubuntu and its derivatives line Linux Mint, Pop!_OS etc.)
- The architecture is compatible (`x86_64` / `amd64`)

Installation will continue **only if all checks pass**, ensuring predictable, safe execution on clean or disposable environments.

docs.title: System info
docs.text:
System Information Collection

This component gathers a detailed snapshot of the host system, including:

- Hostname
- Private and public IP addresses
- MAC addresses for all active interfaces
- Network interface assignments
- DNS resolver configuration
- Kernel version
- OS release and codename
- CPU model and architecture
- Total memory
- Disk usage summary
- CPU load averages
- Machine UUID

This information helps verify whether the host meets required thresholds for container runtimes and Kubernetes components.

docs.title: System requirements
docs.text:
System Requirements

This component is intended for Ubuntu-based environments.

Supported:
- Ubuntu LTS releases
- Linux Mint
- Pop!_OS

Not supported:
- CentOS / RHEL
- Fedora
- Debian (not validated)
- ARM architectures

Only **64-bit (x86_64 / amd64)** systems are supported.

docs.title: System update
docs.text:
System Update & Dependencies

Unless the --no-update flag is passed, this component performs:

- Package index refresh (`apt update`)
- Installation of foundational packages:
    - `curl`
    - `wget`
    - `ca-certificates`
    - `gnupg`
    - `lsb-release`
    - `net-tools`
    - `tree`
    - `jq`

These are required for:
- Secure repository access  
- TLS certificate validation  
- Environment detection  
- Network discovery tools  
- Modern CLI operations

docs.title: 📄 Kubernetes Add-Ons
docs.text:
Networking, Ingress, Gateways, and Traffic Management

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: 🧭 Overview
docs.text:
Kubernetes Add-Ons extend the capabilities of a cluster. They are optional components that enable:

  • Traffic routing
  • Load balancing
  • Ingress management
  • Gateway API support
  • Service mesh integrations
  • L7 traffic control
  • North-south and east-west networking

This page covers the add-ons installed by infra-bootstrap, including:

  1. Gateway API CRDs
  2. NGINX Gateway Fabric
  3. NGINX Ingress Controller (optional)
  4. Traefik (NodePort)

These tools provide a complete ingress and API gateway layer for small clusters, labs, and learning environments.

docs.title: 🧩 What Are Kubernetes Add-Ons?
docs.text:
Add-Ons are not required for the control-plane or worker nodes to function, but they are essential when you want:

  • Exposing applications to the outside world
  • Managing HTTP/HTTPS routing
  • Applying networking rules
  • Running production-like routing in a lab environment
  • Testing real application traffic

The add-ons below provide:

Add-On Purpose Gateway API CRDs Modern Kubernetes L4/L7 routing interface NGINX Gateway Fabric Gateway API implementation by NGINX Ingress-NGINX Traditional Kubernetes Ingress Controller Traefik Ingress + Gateway + L7 routing (NodePort)

docs.title: 🚀 Automatic Installation Script
docs.text:
To install all add-ons:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/k8s-addons.sh | bash

(The script name is assumed; rename accordingly if needed.)

The script installs:

  • Gateway API CRDs
  • NGINX Gateway Fabric
  • NGINX Ingress Controller
  • Traefik Ingress Controller (NodePort)
  • Helm (required for Traefik)

docs.title: 🧱 Add-Ons Installed by infra-bootstrap
docs.text: Below is exactly what your script does and why it matters.

docs.title: 🧊 1. Gateway API CRDs
docs.text:
Gateway API is the next-generation networking API for Kubernetes (successor to Ingress).

Your script installs the official CRDs:

kubectl kustomize "https://github.com/nginx/nginx-gateway-fabric/config/crd/gateway-api/standard?ref=v1.5.1" \
| kubectl apply -f -

docs.title: Why this matters
docs.text:
• Enables GatewayClass, Gateway, HTTPRoute, TCPRoute, etc.
  • Required for NGINX Gateway Fabric
  • Modern L4/L7 routing model
  • More flexible than old Ingress resources

docs.title: 🌐 2. NGINX Gateway Fabric (NodePort)
docs.text:
CRDs first:

kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nginx/nginx-gateway-fabric/v1.6.1/deploy/crds.yaml

Main deployment:

kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nginx/nginx-gateway-fabric/v1.6.1/deploy/nodeport/deploy.yaml

docs.title: What it provides
docs.text:
• Gateway API implementation by NGINX
  • NodePort-based external access
  • High-performance routing engine
  • Easy HTTP/HTTPS traffic management

docs.title: 🌐 3. NGINX Ingress Controller (Optional)
docs.text: kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/controller-v1.13.0/deploy/static/provider/cloud/deploy.yaml

docs.title: What it provides
docs.text:
• Traditional Kubernetes Ingress
  • Stable and widely used in production
  • Works with simple Ingress YAML manifests
  • Good for basic routing workloads

This is optional and not required if you plan to use Gateway API exclusively.

docs.title: ⚡ 4. Traefik (NodePort 32080/32443)
docs.text:
Before Traefik can be installed, your script:

  • Installs Helm v4
  • Adds the Traefik chart repo
  • Updates Helm repository cache

Then installs Traefik:

helm upgrade --install traefik traefik/traefik \
--namespace traefik \
--set ports.web.nodePort=32080 \
--set ports.websecure.nodePort=32443 \
--set service.type=NodePort \
--create-namespace \
--skip-crds

docs.title: What Traefik provides
docs.text:
• Ingress Controller
  • Gateway API support
  • HTTPS termination
  • Automatic certificate management (if enabled)
  • Dashboard support
  • NodePort access on:
Port Purpose 32080 HTTP 32443 HTTPS

docs.title: 🧪 Verification Steps
docs.text: After installation:

docs.title: Check all namespaces:
docs.text: kubectl get ns

docs.title: Check add-on pods:
docs.text: kubectl get pods -A | grep -E "gateway|nginx|traefik"

docs.title: Check Gateway API CRDs:
docs.text: kubectl get crd | grep gateway

docs.title: Check Traefik dashboard (if enabled):
docs.text: http://<node-ip>:32080

docs.title: Check NGINX Fabric resources:
docs.text:
kubectl get gatewayclass
kubectl get gateways
kubectl get httproutes

docs.title: Add-on pods stuck in CrashLoop
docs.text: kubectl logs -n <namespace> <pod-name>

docs.title: Gateway API not working
docs.text:
Check CRDs:

kubectl get crd | grep gateway

docs.title: NodePort not reachable
docs.text: Check firewall or cloud provider security groups.

docs.title: Traefik not installing
docs.text:
Ensure Helm is installed correctly:

helm version

docs.text:

  • NGINX Gateway Fabric: https://github.com/nginx/nginx-gateway-fabric
  • Ingress-NGINX: https://kubernetes.github.io/ingress-nginx

docs.title: 📄 Kubernetes CNI Installation
docs.text:
Script: k8s-cni-setup.sh

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: 🧭 Overview
docs.text:
A Kubernetes cluster created with kubeadm will not schedule pods until a Container Network Interface (CNI) is installed.

The infra-bootstrap CNI installer simplifies this process by:

  • Allowing you to choose Calico, Flannel, or Weave
  • Applying the correct upstream manifest
  • Verifying networking readiness
  • Handling common networking prerequisites

CNI must be installed only on the first control-plane node.

docs.title: 🧩 What a CNI Does
docs.text:
A CNI plugin enables:

  • Pod-to-pod networking
  • Pod IP allocation
  • Routing inside the cluster
  • Network policies (for plugins that support it, e.g., Calico)
  • Cross-node communication

Without a CNI plugin:

  • Pods remain in Pending state
  • kube-dns/CoreDNS cannot start
  • Networking between nodes does not work

docs.title: 🚀 Install CNI (Interactive Script)
docs.text:
Run the infra-bootstrap CNI script:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/k8s-cni-setup.sh | bash

The script will:

  1. Prompt you to choose a CNI
  2. Deploy the selected plugin
  3. Validate pod networking
  4. Check that CoreDNS becomes Ready
  5. Confirm the cluster is operational

docs.title: 📦 Supported CNI Plugins
docs.text: Below are the plugins supported by infra-bootstrap with descriptions and use cases.

docs.title: Why choose Calico?
docs.text:
• Network policies (advanced security)
  • Stable and widely used in production
  • High performance
  • IPv4 and IPv6 support
  • Works on cloud, bare-metal, and labs

docs.title: Manifest used:
docs.text: https://docs.projectcalico.org/manifests/calico.yaml

docs.title: Recommended for:
docs.text:
• Learning production networking
  • Clusters needing NetworkPolicies
  • Multi-node setups

docs.title: Why choose Flannel?
docs.text:
• Very simple
  • Lightweight
  • Perfect for learning
  • No advanced networking complexity

docs.title: Manifest used:
docs.text: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/flannel-io/flannel/master/Documentation/kube-flannel.yml

docs.title: Recommended for:
docs.text:
• Local clusters
  • Lightweight nodes
  • Simple labs

docs.title: Why choose Weave?
docs.text:
• Automatic routing
  • Does not require special config
  • Handles dynamic topology changes
  • Easy installation

docs.title: Manifest used:
docs.text: https://cloud.weave.works/k8s/net?k8s-version=$(kubectl version | base64 | tr -d '\n')

docs.title: Recommended for:
docs.text:
• Quick setups
  • Basic clusters
  • Cloud VMs

docs.title: 🛠 How the k8s-cni-setup.sh Script Works
docs.text:
Your script:

  1. Detects Kubernetes version

  2. Prints supported CNI options

  3. Asks user for selection

  4. Downloads and applies the correct manifest

  5. Waits for:

    • kube-system pods
    • CNI pods
    • CoreDNS readiness

  6. Prints post-installation checks

This ensures the cluster becomes functional immediately after CNI installation.

docs.title: Check pods:
docs.text: kubectl get pods -n kube-system

docs.title: Check node status:
docs.text: kubectl get nodes

docs.title: Check CoreDNS:
docs.text:
kubectl get pods -n kube-system | grep coredns

You should see Running / Ready.

docs.title: Test pod-to-pod networking:
docs.text:
kubectl run test --image=busybox -- sleep 3600
kubectl exec -it test -- ping <another-pod-ip>

docs.title: Pods stuck in Pending
docs.text:
Check CNI pods:

kubectl get pods -n kube-system | grep -E 'calico|flannel|weave'

docs.title: CoreDNS not starting
docs.text: Likely caused by missing CNI. Reinstall the plugin.

docs.title: CNI pods CrashLoop
docs.text:
Check logs:

kubectl logs -n kube-system <pod-name>

docs.title: Nodes show NotReady
docs.text:
Check kubelet status:

systemctl status kubelet

docs.title: 🧹 Reset CNI (Advanced)
docs.text:
To reset an incorrect CNI:

kubectl delete -f <CNI manifest>
kubectl delete pods -n kube-system --all

Then reinstall using the infra-bootstrap script.

docs.title: 📘 Official Documentation
docs.text:
• Calico: https://projectcalico.org
  • Flannel: https://github.com/flannel-io/flannel
  • Weave: https://www.weave.works/docs/net/latest/kubernetes/kube-addon/
  • Kubernetes Networking: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/networking/

docs.title: 📄 Local & Lightweight Kubernetes Clusters
docs.text:
Minikube · Kind · K3s

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: 🧭 Overview
docs.text:
This section covers all methods for running Kubernetes locally for:

  • Learning
  • Labs
  • Testing
  • CI environments
  • Disposable cluster experimentation

These cluster types are not for production. They are designed to be small, fast, and easy to rebuild.

This guide includes the three most widely used local cluster tools:

  1. Minikube
  2. Kind (Kubernetes-in-Docker)
  3. K3s (Lightweight Kubernetes by Rancher)

Each tool comes with a simple one-line command to help you spin up a cluster quickly.

docs.title: 🧊 1. Minikube
docs.text: Minikube is the most common tool for local Kubernetes.

docs.title: Install Minikube
docs.text:
(If not already installed)

curl -LO https://storage.googleapis.com/minikube/releases/latest/minikube-linux-amd64
sudo install minikube-linux-amd64 /usr/local/bin/minikube

docs.title: Start a Cluster
docs.text: minikube start --driver=docker

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text:
minikube status

Minikube automatically deploys a CNI, kubelet, scheduler, and controller manager internally.

docs.title: 🐳 2. Kind (Kubernetes in Docker)
docs.text:
Kind runs Kubernetes inside Docker containers. It is clean, fast, ephemeral, and perfect for labs.

To create a Kind cluster, infra-bootstrap provides two configurations:

docs.title: A) Kind with Calico CNI
docs.text:
curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/k8s-kind-calico.sh | sudo bash

This configuration:

  • Creates 1 control-plane + 1 worker
  • Applies Calico as networking backend
  • Configures API server port mapping
  • Prepares kubeconfig automatically

docs.title: B) Kind with Default CNI (Flannel)
docs.text:
curl -s https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/SilverKube/main/kind-config-file.yaml \
| kind create cluster --config -

This configuration:

  • Uses default Kind networking (based on flannel-style routing)
  • Creates multi-node topology
  • No additional network plugin setup needed

docs.title: ⚡ 3. K3s (Lightweight Kubernetes Engine)
docs.text:
K3s is the smallest, fastest CNCF-certified Kubernetes distribution. Perfect for:

  • VMs
  • Raspberry Pi
  • Small servers
  • Learning Kubernetes without heavy components

Run:

curl -sfL https://get.k3s.io | sh -

docs.title: Verify:
docs.text:
sudo k3s kubectl get nodes

K3s includes:

  • Containerd
  • Flannel networking
  • Lightweight control-plane components
  • Automatic configuration of kubeconfig

docs.title: 🧪 Cluster Verification (All Methods)
docs.text: Regardless of how you created the cluster, verify using:

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This guide explains how to build a self-managed Kubernetes cluster using kubeadm combined with the infra-bootstrap automation scripts.

This method follows the real sequence used by cluster operators:

  • Promote a machine to become a control plane
  • Optionally add more control planes
  • Prepare worker nodes
  • Join all nodes to the cluster
  • Install a CNI plugin
  • Validate the cluster

Everything happens in a SINGLE workflow and a SINGLE page.

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: Step 1 — Create the First Control Plane
docs.text:
Run the following on the machine you want to become the primary control plane:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/K8s-Control-Plane-Init.sh | sudo bash

This script:

  • Prepares the node
  • Cleans previous kubeadm data
  • Starts container runtime + kubelet
  • Runs kubeadm init
  • Configures kubeconfig
  • Produces join commands for workers and additional control planes

After completion, your cluster exists — but with a single control-plane.

docs.title: Step 2 — (Optional) Create Additional Control Planes
docs.text:
If you want multi-control-plane (HA) setup:

Run the same script on your additional control plane nodes:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/K8s-Control-Plane-Init.sh | sudo bash

During initialization of the first node, kubeadm prints the control-plane join command, e.g.:

kubeadm join <API-SERVER-IP>:6443 \
  --token <token> \
  --discovery-token-ca-cert-hash sha256:<hash> \
  --control-plane

Copy that and run it on your additional control-plane nodes.

If the token expired:

kubeadm token create --print-join-command

docs.title: Step 3 — Prepare Worker Nodes
docs.text:
On every node you want to convert into a worker, run:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/K8s-Node-Init.sh | sudo bash

This script:

  • Installs containerd
  • Installs kubelet / kubeadm / kubectl
  • Applies kernel modules + sysctl
  • Enables required services

Each machine becomes Kubernetes-ready.

docs.title: Step 4 — Join Worker Nodes
docs.text:
Joining nodes uses the command printed during the first control-plane init:

kubeadm join <API-SERVER-IP>:6443 \
  --token <token> \
  --discovery-token-ca-cert-hash sha256:<hash>

Run this on each worker node.

If the token expires:

kubeadm token create --print-join-command

docs.title: Step 5 — Install a CNI Plugin (Required for Networking)
docs.text:
Kubernetes will not schedule pods until a CNI is installed.

To deploy a CNI via infra-bootstrap:

curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/k8s-cni-setup.sh | bash

This script:

  • Prompts you to choose Calico, Flannel, or Weave
  • Applies the correct manifest
  • Verifies networking readiness

Important: Install the CNI only once, on the first control-plane node.

docs.title: Check nodes:
docs.text: kubectl get nodes

docs.title: Check system pods:
docs.text: kubectl get pods -A

docs.title: Check control-plane health:
docs.text: kubectl get componentstatuses

docs.title: Check API server readiness:
docs.text:
kubectl get --raw='/readyz?verbose'

If everything is Running/Ready — your Kubernetes cluster is healthy.

docs.title: Reset / Rebuild (if needed)
docs.text:
sudo kubeadm reset -f
sudo systemctl restart containerd
sudo rm -rf ~/.kube

docs.title: Jenkins Server
docs.text: Pre-configured CI/CD lab server: One script bootstraps Jenkins + Docker, kubectl/eksctl, Trivy. Ready for pipelines, builds, and K8s testing. Disposable setup—run, test, wipe.

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
• Runs preflight/system checks.
  • Updates OS and installs Jenkins.
  • Adds Docker, kubectl/eksctl, Trivy.
  • Configures Jenkins user in Docker group.
  • Outputs access URLs and initial password.

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: Run It (Direct)
docs.text: curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/servers/Jenkins-Server.sh | sudo bash

docs.title: Customize (Optional)
docs.text:
Download and edit:

curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/servers/Jenkins-Server.sh
chmod +x Jenkins-Server.sh
nano Jenkins-Server.sh  # Add/remove tools (e.g., skip Trivy)
sudo ./Jenkins-Server.sh

docs.title: What It Installs
docs.text:
• Jenkins: Core CI/CD server (port 8080).
  • Docker: Container runtime (Jenkins user added to group).
  • kubectl + eksctl: K8s management.
  • Trivy: Vulnerability scanner.

docs.title: Access & Verify
docs.text:
• URLs: Local: http://YOUR-IP:8080 | Public: http://PUBLIC-IP:8080 (script outputs both).
  • Initial Password: Script prints it (use to unlock Jenkins setup).
  • Apply Docker Group: Run newgrp docker after setup.
  • Verify: sudo systemctl status jenkins (running?). Login, create first admin user.

Restart if needed: sudo systemctl restart jenkins.

Last updated: {{ git_revision_date_localized }}

docs.title: Jumpbox
docs.text:
Bastion/jump server for lab access: One script sets up Terraform, Ansible, kubectl/eksctl, Helm. Gateway for AWS/K8s management—SSH tunnel, CLI tools bundled.

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: Run It (Direct)
docs.text: curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/servers/Jumpbox.sh | sudo bash

docs.title: Customize (Optional)
docs.text:
Download and edit:

curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/servers/Jumpbox.sh
chmod +x Jumpbox.sh
nano Jumpbox.sh  # Add/remove tools (e.g., skip Helm)
sudo ./Jumpbox.sh

docs.title: What It Installs
docs.text:
• Preflight & Updates: System validation + OS refresh.
  • Terraform: IaC for AWS.
  • Ansible: Config automation.
  • kubectl + eksctl: K8s clients.
  • Helm: K8s package manager.

docs.title: Access & Verify
docs.text:
• Login: SSH to hostname (default user: ubuntu, pass: infra123).
  • Verify: terraform version, ansible --version, kubectl get nodes, helm version.
  • Tunnel Example: ssh -L 8080:k8s:80 ubuntu@jump-ip (forward ports to cluster).

Ready for AWS/K8s ops. Outputs confirmation on run.

docs.title: Nexus
docs.text:
Containerized artifact repository for Maven, Docker, npm. Runs as Docker service—store, proxy, scan packages. Prompt for port on run.

docs.title: Installation Command
docs.text: curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/services/nexus-cont.sh | sudo bash

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
• Runs preflight checks.
  • Installs Docker if missing.
  • Starts Nexus container (sonatype/nexus3, restart=always).
  • Prompts for port (default 8081).

docs.title: Access & Verify
docs.text:
• URLs: Local: http://<YOUR-IP>:<PORT> | Public: http://<PUBLIC-IP>:<PORT> (script outputs both).
  • Password: Script prints admin password (from /nexus-data/admin.password).
  • Verify: sudo docker ps | grep nexus (running?). Access UI, login (admin/password), setup repo.
  • Wait Time: 2-3 min for full startup.

Official Docs: help.sonatype.com/repomanager3

docs.title: System Checks
docs.text:
Validate your lab environment before bootstrapping. Ensures root access, deps. (curl/bash), internet, supported OS (Ubuntu LTS/Debian derivatives), and arch (x86_64/amd64).

Run preflight early—catches issues upfront.

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Preflight: Full system validation (root, deps, OS, arch).
  • System Info: Resource snapshot (RAM, CPU, hostname).
  • Version Check: Installed package audit.

docs.title: Usage Example
docs.text:
curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/system-checks/preflight.sh | sudo bash

Warnings? Fix and retry. Disposable labs start clean.

docs.title: Preflight
docs.text:
Initial system validation before bootstrapping. Checks root, deps (curl/bash), internet, OS (Ubuntu/Linux Mint), arch (x86_64/amd64). Fails fast if not ready.

--8\← "includes/common-header.md" --8\← "includes/system-requirements.md"

docs.title: Installation Command
docs.text: curl -sL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ibtisam-iq/infra-bootstrap/main/scripts/system-checks/preflight.sh | sudo bash

docs.title: What It Verifies
docs.text:
• Root privileges.
  • curl/bash installed.
  • Internet (ping 8.8.8.8).
  • OS compatibility.
  • Architecture.
